intro: Sisymbrium arundanum var. parviflorum, commonly known as the small-flowered broomrape, is a parasitic flowering plant that lacks chlorophyll and relies on host plants for nutrients. It belongs to the family Brassicaceae and is characterized by its yellow or greenish flowers and small, scale-like leaves. The plant typically grows in disturbed soils and is found in regions of Europe and Asia. It has a short life cycle and produces a large number of small seeds that can remain viable in the soil for many years. Due to its parasitic nature, it can have negative impacts on its host plants, particularly in agricultural settings.
